question.title: Code : Merge Sort
question.content:
Given a singly linked list of integers, sort it using 'Merge Sort.'

Note :
No need to print the list, it has already been taken care. Only return the new head to the list.
Input format :
The first line contains an Integer 't' which denotes the number of test cases or queries to be run. Then the test cases follow.

The first and the only line of each test case or query contains the elements of the singly linked list separated by a single space.
Remember/Consider :
While specifying the list elements for input, -1 indicates the end of the singly linked list and hence, would never be a list element
Output format :
For each test case/query, print the elements of the sorted singly linked list.

Output for every test case will be printed in a seperate line.
Constraints :
1 <= t <= 10^2
0 <= M <= 10^5
Where M is the size of the singly linked list.

Time Limit: 1sec
Sample Input 1 :
1
10 9 8 7 6 5 4 3 -1
Sample Output 1 :
 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 10
 Sample Input 2 :
2
-1
10 -5 9 90 5 67 1 89 -1
Sample Output 2 :
-5 1 5 9 10 67 89 90

rephrased.body: Sort a singly linked list of integers using the Merge Sort algorithm. You need to return the new head of the sorted list.

testcases.explanation: The input linked list is 10 -> 9 -> 8 -> 7 -> 6 -> 5 -> 4 -> 3 -> null. After applying merge sort, the sorted linked list is 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6 -> 7 -> 8 -> 9 -> 10 -> null.

The first test case contains an empty linked list (indicated by -1). Thus, the output is an empty linked list which doesn't print anything.
The second test case contains the linked list 10 -> -5 -> 9 -> 90 -> 5 -> 67 -> 1 -> 89 -> null. After sorting, the linked list becomes -5 -> 1 -> 5 -> 9 -> 10 -> 67 -> 89 -> 90 -> null.
